title: The Apprentice candidate Souleyman Bah fired from competition in week three
text:
Souleyman Bah gets fired from The Apprentice in week three (Picture: BBC)

Souleyman Bah is the latest candidate to be fired by Lord Sugar in week three of The Apprentice.

Just 13 contestants remain now that the 20-year-old entrepreneur was booted out of the competition to win the business mogul’s eye-watering £250,000 investment.

Last week the girls were in competition against the boys in a challenge to make an ice lolly product – although the boys lost out as the girls won the task – again.

This resulted in Kenna Ngoma being fired from the competition.

On tonight’s show Lord Sugar decided to make things a bit more interesting by mixing up the groups – and it turns out they didn’t agree on much.

Although the candidates got to have a bit of fun with their challenge as their project was to design and make a toy for a six to eight-year-old child.

It all came down to Riyonn Farsad, Lottie Lion and Souleyman Bah in the boardroom at the end of the task and Lord Sugar didn’t hold back.

There are no words… (Picture: BBC)

Addressing Souleyman Lord Sugar said: ‘You’re opposite to Tommy the Turtle by telling them how crap they are.’

He proceeded to say: ‘I will summarise and I don’t want to hear another word from anyone.

‘Riyonn, this task was a complete failure and it could be easy for me to say “you’re fired”.

‘Lottie I can’t believe that someone so unexperienced tells people the negative points in market research, it’s unforgivable.

‘Souleyman, to put yourself forward and to come in this process was a giant leap and brave, having said that you’re a sportsman and positivity is a strong point in teams but you weren’t bringing any positivity, so it is with regret – you’re fired.’

The 20-year-old Para-Olympian said he both felt confused and shocked that he got fired by Lord Sugar and that ‘it shouldn’t have been him’.

Speaking exclusively to Metro.co.uk, Souleyman said: ‘I thought I was the only one who had any sense in what was wrong with the product, it was an unfortunate case of “I told you so” although I can’t tell them that because I am fired.

‘I think what confused me was usually when you’re fired, it’s when you’re the leader if the task, and the reason the task failed was because the toy wasn’t right for the demographic.

Souleyman felt like the rest of the team tried to ‘sell him out’ (Picture: BBC)

‘We were told that all along, at our target audience meeting, by John Lewis and Hamley’s Toy Shop. We were told it by everyone and I said that right from the beginning and no one chose to listen to me and that is why we failed.’

Advertisement

Souleyman went on to explain who he thought should have been fired instead of him.

He added: ‘The people responsible for the toy was Thomas and his team because they made the toy, and Riyonn because he was the project manager,

‘He has made toys in the past but for some reason he completely detached himself from the project and he just wanted to have fun on stage in front of the camera and that’s unfortunately where I got picked on, despite me making credible points about the product.

‘Tommy or Riyonn should have been fired because they were the ones put in charge.’

Souleyman has left the show after three weeks(Picture: PA)

Having been diagnosed with Retina Pigmentosa at age six, Souleyman also said during the challenge that he felt ‘picked on’ by his fellow teammates.

‘I don’t know why they used my valid points and twisted them to get me fired,’ he said.

‘When I did get fired Lord Sugar said to me that it was “brave” of me to come on the show as a “big leap of ambition”. I felt really patronised by that comment because having a disability people say that to us every day like, “oh you’re so brave” and I just felt that undermined everything I had done.

Advertisement

‘I was picked from 70,000 people and made it to the final 16 people. I felt very belittled and patronised and he has never said that to anyone before so I thought that was unfair.’

The Apprentice continues Wednesday at 9pm on BBC One.
